conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows (A, B, C, and D) cast by four objects change in position and size when the light source moves forward and overhead.
Moving the light forward and overhead means the bulb is translated horizontally toward the objects and raised to be more nearly overhead.
A shadow is always cast on the side opposite the light, so bringing the lamp forward and overhead causes each shadow to migrate rearward (away from the lamp) and become shorter.
The shadow of object A (the hemispherical bowl) slides backward until it sits almost concentrically under the bowl.
The size of shadow A decreases steadily, approaching the diameter of the bowl’s rim when the lamp is directly above.
The shadow of object B (the tall alarm clock) moves rearward in the same way as A.

The size of shadow B shrinks most dramatically because the clock is the tallest object; when the light is overhead, the shadow becomes a thin, almost circular patch corresponding to the clock’s footprint.
The shadow of object C (the low, round cake) shifts rearward.
The size of shadow C, which was already small due to the cake’s low height, becomes a thin halo directly under the cake when the light is overhead.
The shadow of object D (the waffle slice, similar in height to C) migrates rearward in the same way as C.
The size of shadow D shortens slightly and eventually coincides with the rectangular outline of the waffle when the light is overhead.
The relative ordering of shadow offsets visible in the first picture (largest offset for B, then A, etc.) gradually disappears as the lamp moves overhead.
Once the lamp is overhead, all four shadows are directly under their respective objects and are roughly the same size as the objects’ footprints.
